description: Buying and selling of pot in a Monopoly-like game where you want bales of pot rather than Hotels.  The game board and the "Bum Me Out" and "Far Out" cards have colorful cartoon art, but the Pot (property) cards have color photos of the different types of pot you can own.  Simple game with little substance.  Great for collectors of "contraband games," but doesn't get played very often.

Fleet Action is a game concerning large struggles in the Babylon 5 Universe.

From the cover:
Fleet Action is a fast-paced game of starship combat on a fleet scale. No longer are you simply concerned with the actions of just one or two warships. Now you must guide the actions of three dozen at once.

from thr MGDG website:

By the beginning of 1954, both French and Viet Minh realized that the war in Indochina was nearing an end. Ho Chi Minh had requested cease-fire negotiations in Geneva, Switzerland, and the French government was looking for a way out that would give them peace with honor. Both sides felt that a "big win" on the battlefield would finally secure at the peace table what they had been unable to obtain in six and a half years of war.

The site of this battle would be near a village called, in Vietnamese, "Seat of the Border County Prefecture" located in a distant valley of north-western Vietnam near the Laotian border. The French high command, under General Henri Navarre, reasoned that such remote location could not be successfully attacked. General Vo Nguyen Giap thought the position was nearly impossible to defend. The siege of Dien Bien Phu would be the result.

Vallée de la mort is a simulation of this epic siege that ended the French colonial presence in Asia and marked the beginning of a 21-year struggle for national unification. The game is designed for 2 players, one taking the role of the French commander of the fortress complex at Dien Bien Phu, the other of General Giap commanding the Viet-Minh forces laying siege. The game and scenarios are small enough to be played solitaire, however.
Players race to complete their animals by trading cards.  Their are 15 animals to complete, each with three parts.  Ages 4 and up

from the MGDG website:

Early in the 16th Century, an accident of inheritance joined the Low Countries to the sprawling Habsburg Empire. The local governments disliked threats to their traditions of self-rule, and heavy taxes to support foreign wars. At the same time the Protestant Reformation, which was sweeping Europe, found ready acceptance among the affluent, literate Dutch. There was little enough to bind the independent-minded Dutch to the distant Habsburg possessions in Spain and Austria, but the devout Catholicism of the Emperors and their Inquisition now made war inevitable. When the rebellion commenced in 1566, neither side foresaw either the decades of bloody civil war or the formation of an independent Dutch State.

The Dutch Revolt is a simulation of this conflict. One player commands the Catholic forces of the Habsburg Empire under King Philip II of Spain. The other player commands the Dutch Protestant forces under William of Orange.

A unique card deck designed to teach children children basic math concepts using snaps and pairs.  Covers addition, subtraction, multiplication, division, as well as a few square roots, squares, and cubes.  Ages 7 and up

All the players are dealt 5-8 cards, depending on the number of people playing. Each card lists a thing to which a person is likely to have some emotional response. The cards have things as varied as "hip hop," "the smell of oranges," "Brad Pitt," "scoring the winning point," and "breakfast in bed." One player is the Lumper. The other players must give the Lumper a card from their hand that they think he/she will like a lot. The Lumper then arranges the cards on a board, which has spaces for Like It (10 points), Thumbs Up (7 points) A-OK (5 points), Not Bad (3 points), So So (2 points), Whatever (1 point), and Lump It (negative 5 points). The players earn (or lose) points depending on where their card was placed. The role of Lumper moves to the left, and when everyone has been a Lumper a prescribed number of times, the game ends. The highest score wins.

Tactical, topological tile game. It's set in medieval Northern Germany where four merchants set off to sell their goods in other towns and have to discover the safest and shortest roads for themselves, thereby avoiding many obstacles and roughness.

In the far off distant future, corporations vie for control of new worlds and the resources they comprise. Using five 8-sided dice printed with colorful icons, players vie to land explorers, miners, bases, and supply ships on a newly-discovered planet. Watch out, though - your opponent's dice can knock into yours, disrupting your carefully laid explorations!

You need to print and assemble the dice yourself. Paper is OK, but 110lb cardstock is better. Surprisingly, once folded and glued, the dice have a fair bit of weight to them - not enough to put someone's eye out, but enough for the game to be playable.

The commercial PDF also included a cut-n-assemble box to keep the components in once you've cut and folded. The free version does not.

All-in-the-Dice Baseball is an exciting dice game that simulates all of the action found in professional baseball. There are hits, outs, walks, steals, and erros. Although the results of each play are in the dice, it is the player who determines the strategy to be employed. The game has been statistically perfected so that it is accurate within 2% of professional baseball. Anyone with an understanding of the game of baseball will have endless hours of fun playing the game. AITD can be played with 1 or 2 players. The rules are below in the image section.

Conhex is a 2-player abstract game in which the winner is the first player to connect his or her assigned sides of a square board (thus the goal is similar to the goal in Twixt.)  The board is a pattern of non-regular hexagons with a few non-hexagonal polygons.  Players alternate turns placing pieces of their own color on a vertex, and a player can claim a space after placing pieces on at least half the vertices of that space.  A description can be found at www.gamerz.net and the game can be played face-to-face or over the internet.

Zamitar is a chess style game with very 70’s inspired sci-fi acrylic pieces. Each piece has it’s own move, as in a normal chess game. The difference being that a few of the pieces can bounce their moves off the walls.
To win you must take the opponents Space Station piece. The astronaut piece definitely has a “Danger - Will Robinson” (from the old LOST IN SPACE TV Show)  feel about it. It is possible to purchase two other forces so you can have a four-player version.

Game from Strategy & Tactics magazine #180.

Wargame covering the first few weeks of the German offensive in the west, 1914.

There's gold in them thar hills!

In Boomtown — a game with auctions, dice, and fun/nasty action cards to play on opponents — you start as a gold digger and try to end as a tycoon. To do this, you must first buy the best mining concessions, hoping to find gold veins. You can also try to become the Mayor of Whiskey River or San Narciso, in order to get a small cut on concessions sales, or build a saloon where lucky prospectors will spend their nuggets in moonshine whiskey. If business is really bad, you can still rely on bank or stagecoach hold-ups to reestablish you. A well placed stick of dynamite can also solve some minor problems.

Piraci features the same gameplay as Boomtown, but with the players now sailing the waters instead of panning them.

From the publisher's website:

The best pupils from the school of magic gather to try out their most powerful spells. But be careful of their clumsy broomstick! A game of forming combinations for apprentice wizards.

From the publisher's website:

Research into natural science requires careful planning - especially when only one specimen can be taken for the collection. And how much better if it is a species of Farfalia! A trick taking game for alert naturalists.

Roll the die and move around the board. If you land on a letter square, draw a card with a long word on it. You have 60 seconds to find the longest word using the letters in the card word. You move a variable number of spaces depending on the length of the found word. The other players can challenge you by spelling out a longer word. There is a small dictionary that lists all spellable words for each card word. Game includes over 400 word cards, 25 tokens for scoring, 1 d6 and a 1 min sand timer.
The aim of the game is for players to get all aircraft into the airport and airborne again as quickly as possible to beat the other players.

A children's game where the object is to be the last player in the game.  A plastic and cardboard boat (divided into colored quarters) is balanced on the corners of the box.  A spinner dictates the placement of a pirate mouse on a colored section of the boat.  If all the pirates are placed onto the boat, the spinner then dictates which pirates are removed from the boat.  A players that causes the pirates to fall into the ocean (box) is eliminated from the game.  The remaining player is declared the winner.  Game art was done by Richard Scarry.

Ancient Conquest is a classic and highly rated multiplayer game covering at a grand strategic level the rise and fall of empires and peoples in the ancient near east. Roughly covering the period from the New Kingdom of Egypt to the Age of Four Kingdoms (chronologically from 1500 BC to 600 BC), the game combines the diplomacy and political objectives of the involved peoples and empires of this period with a fast-moving and playable combat system. Ancient Assyria, Egypt, Babylon and the Hittites are all included, as well as numerous other powers.

Ancient Conquest is a highly accurate game, historically speaking, though it is built around some elegantly simple mechanisms.

Help Emily, Bagpuss and friends find homes for the lost things.

This game is based on the children’s TV series, Bagpuss about an old toy cat and his friends; toys that come to life to study the lost things their owner Emily brings into her special shop. Players move around the board taking penalties, extra goes or collecting cards with pictures of one or more of the characters from the series on them. Whenever a player has a complete set of all of the characters they can trade them in for a card from the 'lost things' pile. When all of the lost things have been drawn the player with the most wins.

Easiest description is likely that this game plays similar to Spades.  It uses a regular deck of 52 playing cards, it is about taking tricks to match a 'bid' (assigned in 7-4-1 versus bidding in Spades), with Aces high and a trump suit (declared in 7-4-1 versus always spades in Spades).

In 7-4-1, 12 cards are dealt to each of the 4 players; this leaves a 4-card kitty.  The dealer MUST try to take 7 tricks, but she gets to declare which suit is trump AFTER looking at her hand.  She then gets to pick up the 4 middle cards, and discard 4 face-down (could be from the kitty, or not).  Player 2 must get 4 tricks, player 3 for 1 trick, and player 4 need not take any.

After round 1, figure out how many cards more or less players got.  YOu get one point for every trick you make above your required tricks, and lose one for every trick you fail to make.  For the next round, a player who had MORE in the previous round can then pass one card per amount more to a player who had less; that lesser player must then pass their HIGHEST card in each requested suit.  Some pre-defined ordering for this is necessary; the player needing to make the most tricks has precedence over the player needing less.

For example, in round 1, the players take 6-2-3-1 tricks.
So, the position 2 is now the new dealer.  Player in position 3 was +2 in round 1 (took 3, needed 1), and would ask position 1 for 1 suit, and position 2 for 1 suit.  Player in position 4 would then ask position 2 for 1 suit.  We've played where if the numbers over/under match (position 3&2, 4&1 in this example), then they could simply swap cards too.

Play then proceeds as described above.  Trump is declared AFTER the card-swapping is done.  And if the player who needed 4 in the previous round took NONE, then they can also look at the kitty too before declaring a trump!  However, they'd also have just given up 4 good cards to other players...\
Game ends after either 2 or 3 rounds, with everyone getting a chance at each position an equal number of times.

Public domain card game which plays with a regular deck of cards.  The idea is to get rid of all your cards FIRST.  Everyone gets some number of starting cards (like 5), and must play a matching card (colour/suit/value), or pick up 1 from the 'stock' pile, and either play THAT or pass.

There are many variants, according to Hoyle.  Some have 8s as the wild card (any colour/value), while other use Jacks - hence the alternate names.  All seem to have at least one 'pick up #' card, and one 'skip a turn' card.

Variants also include pick-up 2s, which could accumulate if more 2s were played consecutively (pick up 4, 6, or 8), and Jacks as the skip-a-turn.  In other variants played with 4s as skip-a-turns, Aces as pick up 1s and Queen of Spades as pick up 5.

Crazy Eights is the game upon which the commercial UNO is based.

Campaign Secrets is a political card game where you are a candidate in the race for the White House. You must out-campaign your opponents to win the favor of your constituents. And most importantly, don't let those voters find out about your dirty little secrets!

Campaign Secrets is a fun educational game. Each card has tidbits about real presidential elections. In addition, the campaign strategies and secrets in the game, are all taken from real-life strategies and scandals. Playing the game can give many children and adults alike an insight into how a real election comes together.

In the game, you play a series of campaign strategies trying to get more percentage of the vote than the other players in the game. Eventually, through game play, you'll either choose or stumble into your running mate. Together the two of you must do your best to wrangle as many votes as possible away from the other players, and to hold on to your secrets so you can pick up a few extra votes at the end of the game.

The game was designed for families and classrooms, so while it can be fun and educational for hard-core gamers, it's still simple enough for everybody to play. If you're looking for a fun way to learn about the election process, or just a fun game to play with your family, then this is the game for you. If you're looking a hard-core strategy game then you might want to look elsewhere.

NOTE: You may have played the First Edition of this game, but the Second Edition plays considerably different. The first edition was a quick and dirty version put out as a free give away for trade shows, the second edition is the real game.

Pig Dice, an ancestor of Pass the Pigs and a descendant of Pig, is a jeopardy dice game, where the dominant type of decision is whether or not to jeopardize previous gains by rolling for potential greater gains.  In particular, Pig Dice is a jeopardy race game, where the object is to be the first to meet or exceed a goal score.

One die is a standard die with a pig head replacing the 1.  The other is a standard die with a pig tail replacing the 6.  Such rolls are called Heads and Tails, respectively, and modify the value of the roll.  The goal score is 100, yet after a player has met or exceeded 100, all other players have one more turn to achieve a higher score.

Each collectable Nak Nak figure can be posed in over 80 different stacking poses. Object is to see how many NAKNAK figures you can stack. 
Each Player takes turns rolling 2 dice, one die determines if u stack your Nak Nak on the ground or on the stack on top of another Nak Nak. The other die determines what body part of the Nak Nak that need to be touching the stack or ground. 
If a player drops the stack the player who went before him takes the Nak Naks that fell off the stack, Last player with Nak Naks Wins.

Don't Drop Anything, Little Raven!  How much can the little raven carry?  The small raven is moving house. There are many things from the old nest that must be brought to the new nest. And because the small raven wants to carry everything all at once, players try to attach as many different objects as possible on the raven's figure. The screen over the wing, the pocket to the tail, the cake on the head... Pay attention so that nothing falls off.

Explore the world! You've been transported to a mystery location - now figure out where you are. Race around the board to collect clues...the first player to put clues together and figure out the mystery location wins the game.

REICH portrays events in Germany between the Reformation and the unification engineered by Bismarck. Players are not bound to a pre-determined sequence of events; rather, major social forces are used to compose game elements. These include Marxist agitation, religious riots, peasant uprisings, revolts, Papal recognition, key ministers (like the Iron Chancellor himself), foreign intervention and aid, mobilizations and wars, etc., making up a game system both exciting and flavorful.

Each player becomes a Prince attempting to unify a fragmented Germany by means of adroit diplomacy, cunning bargains, and sudden mobilizations and armed strikes. Each turn allows for card play and interaction, then demands that the phasing player choose one of four exclusive policies in the ensuing Action Phase. Player intelligence, elan, and flexibility determine a game's outcome, with little reference to luck. Opportunities for conclusive action are many, but must be seized decisively and courageously. Winning or losing, REICH is a memorable and enjoyable experience for every player.

Time Travel Baseball included players from early 1900s to the late 70s. Expansion sets included players in the early 80s. The game also had special rules to allow you to play in various eras of baseball. These special era rules allowed you to see how players of the 70s may have fared when playing in the dead-ball era. One of the expansion sets you would even included a player card with your name on it when you ordered from the manufacturer.

Taken from the publisher's website:

In this heavily  armed card game, you take on the role of  a military superpower. Your mission: To  obtain 100 points worth of property. And  we're not talking property like your grandmother's 2 story house, or a Ford  Pinto with 56 thousand miles on it, we  mean Washington D.C., Moscow, and Rome to  name a few.

Game play wise, don't expect to see  the "honorable" warfare that died off in the samurai centuries.  Now-a-days, we've got spies, blackmail,  market manipulation, terrorism, and of  course, the ever popular nuclear bomb,  which has the ability to completely  annihilate any city quicker than you can  yell "HEY! What the?!?!" Now THAT's a great Sunday family activity!

With Global Supremacy, expect to lose  your mind… The speed of the game is  fast, so keep a clear head or you'll lose  it, along with any chances of winning the  game. Sound fun? It does to me, too! So  pick Global Supremacy up, since the price  matches all other products here at  WM… Nothing.

Global Supremacy can be downloaded at whitemask.com

From the box bottom:

This entertaining information game combines risk-taking and strategy.  A roll of the giant 12-sided die determines the category you'll answer, or which special instruction you'll follow.

If you roll a category, you must decide how much you know in that field.  Is Sports your best category?  Then bet you'll win the maximum $100.  Not sure about Entertainment?  Then select $50.  Totally adrift in Science?  Then try the easiest $25.  Keep in mind you're trying to be the first player to win $750 in game chips.

Each side of each card has three clues, all leading to the same answer.  The clues range from difficult to easy, but all will be informative and fun.  There are 1,200 different answers and 3,600 clues in all, so the game can be played many times.

Special instructions on the die, such as Double or Their Choice, give the game real variety.  As an added twist, you can challenge your opponent if you think he or she has bet more than he or she knows.
A hybrid of rock-paper-scissors and checkers in which players move pieces of four kinds over a cross-shaped board.

No Middle Ground' is a simulation of the Syrian Offensive (Operation Badr) at the beginning of the Yom Kippur War. The Syrians were attempting to breakthrough to the highly populated Israeli territories to the west, as well as drawing Israeli air and ground forces from their Egyptian allies offensive in the Sinai. The game is intended to be an easy-to-learn game suitable for novices, as well as a challenging and fun contest for veteran grognards.

The 11 x 17 map depicts the Golan Heights at 4 km per hex.
The 168 counters represent Israeli battalions and Syrian and Arab-allied units brigades.

Fiasco describes itself as a recently discovered card game thought to date from the Italian Renaissance of the late-1450s. Fiasco distinctively incorporates six suits representing symbols of power and wealth and features the legendary character Fiasco.

A game for advanced card players, Fiasco is easy to learn but a challenge to master. First, select your favorite suit. Choose from horses, swords, mandolins, roses, books or treasure chests. Now do your best to collect them all. Play high cards to win the pot and accumulate points. But here’s the twist: Playing high cards also gives your opponents the opportunity to hit you with Fiasco penalty cards. Avoid the danger by laying low, but lose the chance to win your points.

Save The World is a cooperative board game for 2 to 6 players, in which the players team up to stop all the ecological crises that threaten the earth's survival. Players strategize together and have a 50-50 chance of staving off the end of the world.

--From the designer:
"My lifelong passion is the environment. I've been an alarmist eco-nut since the 60's, when as editor of the Los Angeles Free Press, the grandaddy of the underground press, I became aware of the man-made threats to habitation on the planet. In 1980, I created Save the World, the cooperative environmental board game. Players were confronted with all the threats to the planet and offered all the solutions, with the idea of taking them out into real life.  So far, the game has not achieve its mission. When I started research for Save the World, I didn't think we'd be around this long. After two years of study, I concluded that a small number of humans would survive, and a small number of other species: some consolation, I guess. I'm pleasantly surprised that we're still here, but the long-term prospects are still not encouraging."

In CARTEL: The International Oil Game, you try to become the wealthiest player, and therefore, the winner. You will try to invest in oil fields throughout the world, and sell any crude oil that you obtain for the most profit. The first player to obtain ten million petro-dollars in cash is the winner of the game.

Note: This is not the same thing as the Philip Orbanes game Cartel.

"Barbarossa: Game of the Russo-German War 1941-45"

On 22 June 1941, the German Wehrmacht invaded Soviet Russia in an operation code-named Barbarossa. 
Barbarossa is a Strategic level, two-player, Corps-level board wargame simulation of the four year struggle of the East Front War in the Soviet Union. The Axis Player takes the role of the German High Command (OKH) and controls playing pieces representing the forces of Germany and its allies. The Soviet player takes the role of the Soviet High Command (STAVKA) and controls pieces representing the armed forces of Soviet Russia and allied partisans.

Four scenarios:
1941 Barbarossa: Turns 1 through 8
1942 Blau: Turns 12 through 24
1943 Zitedelle: Turns 26 through 36
Campaign: Turns 1 through 48

Game Scale:
Game Turn: 1 month
Hex: 27 miles / 44 kilometers
Units: Corps to Army

Solitaire Playability: Medium
Complexity Level: High
Players: 2 or more
Playing Time: 4-25 hours

Spin and move game based on the 1981 MGM movie, Clash of the Titans has each player taking on the role of Perseus.  Each Perseus is trying to gather the Medusa's head and the five magic items needed to pass the five obstacles in a race to the finish where he will show the Medusa's head to the Kraken and win the game.

Battle of the Bulge, December, 1944

Bastogne or Bust! recreates the Battle of the Bulge at the operational level of scale. The units represent companies, battalions, and regiments that either participated in the battle or were available for committment by their respective commanders. Althought the game is moderate in complexity, it can be easily taught to those who are new to wargaming. Bastogne or Bust! has numerous special rules to deal with situations that were unique to this battle. There are German Fuel Shortages, the Einheit Steilau Commandos, Skorzeny's 150th Commando Brigade, and a Von Der Heydte Parachute Battalion that actually gets onto the map! A system of off-board movement and combat ensures that the action is no confined to the game map.

Number quest is a game of making numbers from the combination of the roll of 4 dice.
The game consists of a Diamond shaped board separated into 100 hexes numbered 1 to 100.Numbers 1 and 100 start at opposite ends of the diamond and the rows in between are filled in by the following combinations.
Coloured orange 1,2-3,4-6,7-10,11-15,
Coloured turquoise 16-21,22-28
Coloured yellow 29-36,37-45
Coloured  blue 46-55,56-64
Coloured green 65-72,73-79
Coloured purple 80-85,86-90
Coloured red 91-94,95-97,98-99,100
All of the numbers are printed in black except for the prime numbers which are printed in white.
On a players turn they roll 4 dice and try to make a number by addition,  subtraction, multiplication or division using each number once and all four numbers.Once the number is made they cover the number with a token and receive a reward dependent on the numbers value.The reward given will be orange section 10,turquoise section 20,yellow section 50,blue section 100,green section 200,purple section 300 and the red section 500.It is then the next players turn to make a new number by rolling the dice.However numbers covered over are out of the game.
If a player places a token to form a triangle of 3 hexes then they gain a bonus of 100,If the number covered that form the triangle is a prime number then the bonus is 200.
If a player can not form a number on their turn then they miss a go.

Four game in the Western Desert 1941-1943. Standard rules and Exclusive rules for each of the four games.

    Crusader, Battle for Tobruk, November 1941
    Cauldron, Battle of Gazala, May 1942
    Supercharge, Battle of El Alamein, October 1942
    Kasserine, Baptism of Fire, February 1943.

(From the Publisher)
 Fantasy Rules! 3rd edition 2004 
Chipco's Fantasy Rules! lets you game in the worlds of fantasy and mythology with rules that are easy, flexible, innovative, fast, and fun. Fantasy Rules! may be played with any figures currently in your collection and playing time is around one hour for typical armies. Armies are generally made up of 30 to 50 figures. Characters are included in the system, but are not so powerful as to overly influence and unbalance the outcome of the game.

* FR!3 may be played with any figures you have and is very well suited for use with figures mounted on slotted bases
    * FR!3 is designed for use with 15mm or 25mm armies
    * FR!3 is tied to no figure manufacturer
    * The movement system is based on previous, proven Chipco game systems
    * There are over 60 army lists included, featuring both mythical historical and pure fantasy - from legendary Ancient Egypt, Greece, and Rome to new lists for Napoleonic, American Civil War, Buffalo Soldiers, Native Americans, Faerie, Automaton, Arabian Nights, and Victorian armies. From Gnomes, Elves, and Orcs to Hive Queens and Arch Angels or Demon Lords
    * FR!3 streamlines the 2nd edition magic system, adds new units and abilities, and makes characters more flexible while keeping the core system
    * Battles are not limited to open ground. FR!3 includes rules for flying, swimming, and burrowing troops
    * FR!3 adds a whole new dimension with rules for cities, walls, and ships
    * Gamers upgrading from FR!2 will appreciate that a version of FR!3 is available with any changes from the 2nd edition marked
    * The rules take advantage of the book-marking capability of Adobe Acrobat and are also indexed
    * FR!3 can easily be played on the typical kitchen table (3' x 4'). It can be expanded to battles of any size, and used to resolve large battles in RPGs
    * Approximately 150 pages, with reference tables, etc.

First edition - 1996
Second edition - 1998
Third edition - 2004
Fantasy Rules! Tournament & Campaign Edition (TCE) - 2008

From the Kadon web site:

A gameboard like no other — the grid is a swirl of arches, a network of intersections. Three intriguing games of positional and movement strategy employ a unique element:  a piece flips on every move from slider to jumper and back again. In Endpoint your goal is to exit all 15 of your pieces from the board through the opponent's home row. In End Jam you win if all the opponent's endpoints are occupied. In End Rush each player seeks to capture the board's center space. Some solitaire puzzles are also included. Cylindrical wood playing pieces have felt on one side to indicate their status. The 24" gameboard is offered in two formats, recommended for Ages 10 and up.

Two teams try to describe and guess ideas - nothing could be simpler!

Or perhaps not,  as each player in the team must say one word in turn.  And his word and those of his fellow team members must make a grammatically correct sentence.  Not so easy if each person is thinking along different lines!  For each correct answer,  that team's playing token moves nearer the goal.

From the old time television show of the 1950's. (remember Dorothy Killgalen and Bennett Cerf!).

That's one down and nine to go.... From the show that coined the phrase, "is it bigger than a breadbox?" What's My Line is the classic guessing game. Players ask yes or no questions to unravel the unusual occupation of the guest contestant. Get a no answer and play moves on to the next guesser. With photos of actual people, a TV screen to put them in, and blindfolds like the ones on the classic game show, What's My Line is destined to evoke memories, laughter and hours of endless fun.

Trick taking card game (capture a specific amount),with new scoring system ( 1st-4th place in bid accuracy). No more great cards dealt determining winner here, as each player has control over his own scoring. Each player has 9 lives to begin game,if you lose them all you are replaced by a Computer player and game continues. (internet version) Game play is 6-12 hands, approx.20-40 minutes
CP has exact rules of play. Game has 6 tie-breakers, as scoring is close (12-10-8-6)Also has a"halo" rule. Game is singles play, no partnerships, spades always trump suit. web add is www.skillcat.com

Every Player (Patient) get 4 Symptom Cards that show their Brain disease. 
On the Symptom Cards is a List of Treatments that you must take step by step from the Top to the Bottom to heal the disease. 
To heal you must visit some Places in turn (First the Doctor,Then the Drugstore, ect...)and pay there Money for the Treatment.If more than one Card need the same Treatment at the same Time, you must only pay once for all same Treatments. That save Time and Money.
To win the Game you must Cure all 4 Diseases.

In the Game box:
 1 Gameboard
 1 Bottle with Clips (To mark the last Treatment of Symptom Card you take.)
33 Symptom Cards 
54 Brainstorm Cards (17 Good,17 Bad)
A lot of Game money

CONTENT:
a central board
a number of square tiles depicting parts of caterpillars: heads, bodies, tails

OBJECT 
to match the heads, bodies and tails to score the number of points shown on the bodies.

An entertaining game for children which plays very similar to Carcassonne. Place a tile wherever it matches and claim the points.
I introduced the variant of providing each player with a counter, so they can claim one bug as their own to be finished later, like in Carcassonne. That way, players are not exposed to be stolen their bugs and encouraged to build longer bugs.

It turns to be quite fun due to the pictures and also when any child by mistake place two heads or two tails together....  X-Mutant bugs!!

CONTENTS:
colorful board
plastic transparent over board with holes to hold the spinners
4x 3 spinners

PLAY
Each player takes 3 tops of the same color and spins one top per turn from his colored bay, which is his starting area.
The tops will stop in one of the numbered holes (2-3-4 o 5)
The players write down their scores after the 3 turns and start all over again.

You can play to 100, 200 or more points.

CONTENTS
Playing board
4x player pieces (boys) with bases and 1 witch
16 rubber creatures (ingredients): 3x spiders, bats, lizards and snakes; 1x skull, bone, toad, rat.
1 green frog head
1 cauldron with spring handle
1 special d6 (1|2|3|4|witch|frog)

OBJECT of the GAME
Collect the 3 particular ingredients you need from the creepy cauldron (as listed in the spell book in your home base); once you have them, obtain the key from the mouth of the ugly witch's cauldron and make it to the exit.

But there are terrifying dangers: both the witch and the cauldron will try to get you before you escape!

A children's game with a fright!

From the box:

"Like the popular NOVA television program on PBS, the NOVA TRUE SCIENCE game will intrigue and entertaining science-phobes and science-philes alike. Players wander around a Big Brain Game Board and earn points by answering simple true-false questions or tougher "genius" questions. The 900 questions fall into six science categories: Life, Earth, Physics, Technology, Science & Society, and Random Access (anything goes). Players can use Brain Boost and Cross Current spaces to take strategic shortcuts. Plus, they can even bet on their opponent's science knowledge by taking an Einstein's Gamble."

Game includes Big Brain Game Board, 4 playing pieces, 200 True/False cards, 100 Genius cards, 1 die, and Rule Booklet which includes a brief glossary of science terms.

A joint effort by Aristoplay and WGBH-Boston Educational Foundation, producers of NOVA.

Here is a description of the game from Selecta Spielzeug:

Using their imagination and power of perception, children learn to recognize the whole picture by seeing only a part of it. Put all the guessing cards in the box and remove one puzzle piece after the other. All players guess diligently until the image on the first card is recognized. Contents: 1 wooden box, 6 puzzle pieces with wooden knobs, 10 double-sided guessing cards, 1 illustrated picture card, instructions
This is a tile placement game involving the metamorphosis from an Indian to an African elephant. Mainly for children but fun for the whole family.
